message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Desflurane is a halogenated ether used as an anesthetic. It can cause respiratory depression as well as an increased risk of increased intracranial pressure. Option A is incorrect as it is not a known effect of desflurane. Option B is also incorrect as it is not a known effect of desflurane. Option C is also incorrect as there is no known effect of desflurane on seizure thresholds.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Desflurane is a volatile inhalational agent that can cause respiratory depression. It is also known to increase intracranial pressure, making option (D) the most likely. Options (A), (B), and (C) are not associated with the effects of desflurane.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Desflurane is an inhalation anesthetic that can cause respiratory depression, leading to increased CO2 retention, and increased intracranial pressure due to vasodilation. None of the other options are associated with desflurane anesthesia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Desflurane is a type of volatile anesthetic that can cause respiratory depression, which can lead to increased pCO2 and intracranial pressure. Therefore, the most likely effect in response to this drug is increased intracranial pressure. Increased glomerular filtration rate, increased cerebral metabolic rate, and decreased seizure threshold are not commonly associated with desflurane anesthesia.

It can also increase intracranial pressure, which is why it is contraindicated in patients with increased intracranial pressure. It does not affect the glomerular filtration rate, cerebral metabolic rate, or seizure threshold.
